description.other_details: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/.

SOGC Fetal health Surveillance: antepartum and intrapartum Consensus Guideline: http://www.sogc.org/guidelines/documents/gui197CPG0709r.pdf
Intrapartum care: management and delivery of care to women in labour: http://www.nice.org.uk/nicemedia/live/11837/36275/36275.pdf

details.purpose: To record observations about the fetal heart rate, usually using a cardiotocograph or similar device over a time in late pregnancy or labour, as an assessment about fetal wellbeing in utero.
details.use:
Use to record observations about the fetal heart rate, usually using a cardiotocograph or similar device over a period of time in late pregnancy or labour, as an assessment about fetal wellbeing.
Use to capture findings from electronic monitoring, including cardiotocography.
Use is restricted to recording details about the heart beat of a fetus.
details.misuse:
Not to be used to record simple, intermittent measurements of fetal heart rate - use the parent archetype OBSERVATION.fetal_heart instead.
Not to be used for recording the heart rate of infants, children or adults.

items.items: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The fetal heart beat is detected.
Implied as present if fetal heart rate > 0.
Additional narrative about the fetal heart rate, not captured in other fields.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the fetal heart rate.
The position of the mother when the fetal heart rate was measured.
Mother standing at the time of fetal heart rate measurement.
Mother sitting at the time of fetail heart rate measurement.
Mother reclining at the time of fetal heart rate measurement.
Lying flat at the time of fetal heart rate measurement.
Mother lying flat with some lateral tilt towards the left.
Description of incidental factors, not recorded elsewhere, that may be influencing the fetal heart rate measurement.
For example, maternal fever or exertion.
Details about the device used to detect the fetal heart rate.
For example: Pinard's stethoscope or Doppler Ultrasound.
The fetal heart beat is detected.
The fetal heart beat is not detected.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Is the mother in active labor during the observation?
The mother is in labour as the observation is made.
The mother is not in labour as the observation is made.
Observations about the fetal heart rate, usually using a cardiotocograph or similar device over a period of time.
Variability in the fetal heart rate observed during the monitoring interval.
Variability in the fetal heart rate observed during the monitoring interval.
Narrative description of the pattern of variability observed during the monitoring interval.
Presence of accelerations observed during the monitoring interval.
Frequency of early accelerations observed during the monitoring interval.
Frequency of uncomplicated variable decelerations observed during the monitoring interval.
Frequency of complicated variable decelerations observed during the monitoring interval.
Frequency of late decelerations observed during the monitoring interval.
Duration of a single, prolonged deceleration observed during the monitoring interval.
Can be recorded multiple times during the period of observation - one duration recorded for each discrete deceleration.
Digital representation of the monitoring findings.
For example: video or recording of the CTG.
Heart rate variability is greater than undetectable, but less than or equal to 5 beats per minute.
Heart rate variability is between 6-25 beats per minute.
Heart rate variability is greater than 25 beats per minute.
Heart rate accelerations are present and occurring spontaneously.
Fetal heart accelerations are detected as a result of fetal scalp stimulation.
Fetal heart rate accelerations are not detected with fetal scalp stimulation.
Occasional decelerations detected but occur in association with less than 50% of uterine contractions.
Decelerations detected in association with over 50% of uterine contractions.
Occasional decelerations detected but occur in association with less than 50% of uterine contractions.
Decelerations detected in association with over 50% of uterine contractions.
Occasional decelerations detected but occur in association with less than 50% of uterine contractions.
Decelerations detected in association with over 50% of uterine contractions.
Occasional decelerations detected but occur in association with less than 50% of uterine contractions.
Decelerations detected in association with over 50% of uterine contractions.
